info.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 09 at 5:48PM EST until January 11 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a Flood Advisory for the following rivers in South Carolina... Saluda River At West Pelzer affecting Anderson and Greenville Counties. .Heavy rainfall has ended across the upper Saluda River watershed. Storm-total rainfall of 4-5 inches occurred across the watershed, resulting in significant rises above bankfull on several smaller tributaries across northern Greenville County. Significant rises to near bankfull have occurred on the South, Middle, and North Saluda Rivers as well. The floodwaves have crested on all three forks of the upper Saluda River and is now moving down the Saluda River. It will take another 8-12 hours for the floodwave to move through Piedmont, Pelzer, and Ware Shoals causing nuisance flooding of adjacent low-lying areas near the river, including to farmland, parks, boat-access areas, residential yards, and the lowest elevations of secondary roads. ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM THIS AFTERNOON TO THURSDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...Saluda River at West Pelzer. * WHEN...From this afternoon to Thursday morning. * IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, Action Stage. The woodlands along both sides of the river are flooding. Water will enter a backyard of one home on Arden Road near Culbertson road. Parts of Pelzer boat ramp and yards of some homes along Adger Street in Anderson County will be flooded. Arden Road will be flooded by a couple inches of flood waters. At 12.0 feet, Minor Flood Stage. Further flooding of woodlands and fields downstream of gage will occur. Additional flooding of the area around the Pelzer boat ramp will occur and floodwaters will continue to impact adjacent yards. Flooding of Arden Road will continue. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 5:25 PM EST Tuesday the stage was 11.1 feet and rising steadily. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 11.9 feet tomorrow morning. - Action/Advisory Stage is 11.0 feet. - Minor Flood Stage is 12.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an alternative route. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. For detailed information including observed and forecast stages, flood impacts, flood history, FEMA Flood Hazard Layers, and more, please visit: https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=gsp The next statement will be issued before Thursday morning at 700 AM EST.
